title: How can a researcher be a scientist? - Quora

response.answer_text: A really basic idea is that the best, most excruciating scientists try to falsify notions, whether the notion originates from them or from someone else. Scientists are thus a subset of all the people who call themselves researchers. This idea is tossed on the sidewalk and danced upon in practice. People with what appear to be serious credentials try to use these to push nonsense ideas. People with apparently serious credentials cherry-pick data or theories when it suits their belief systems, and likewise cherry-pick evidence that seems to oppose scientific theories they don’t like. Fortunately, you don’t need credentials to be a scientist. Look at Michael Faraday: he had very little formal education, but is regarded today as one of the founders of the sciences of electrochemistry and electromagnetism. What you need is Faraday’s wisdom, which is to set aside received knowledge, and set about proving ideas for one’s self. If you do this, you will be both a researcher and a scientist.

How can a researcher become a scientist? This is an excellent question. Please note both terminology is interchangeable. A researcher can become a scientist and a scientist can become a researcher. How is this possible? Well, one need basic education and clear planning and to secure a position in an academic or research or NHS establishment. Typically, having a bachelor or master degree will help. Those with PhD degree can become team leader etc. Also, ability to conduct investigation is essential. Both positions are very rewarding and lead to discovery of things that community need to empower and upgrade.

How do I become a scientist when I am a researcher? These two words are like synonyms with slight difference. But for practical purposes, there is no big difference, mainly it is a matter of convention. Usually a researcher is one who does any kind of research ( even in literature, or sociology or non-science topics), while a scientist is the one who do research in science, and is affiliated with certain organizations. So, work in any scientific organization, you will be called a scientist. If start working on any topic with research bent of mind, you can claim as a researcher.

“How can a researcher be a scientist?” “Research” is the broader concept. “Scientific research” is the narrower concept. Scientists do scientific research. All scientists are researchers. Scientists do research in a field or fields of science. Not all researchers are scientists. Historians, for instance, may do research by finding, studying, and drawing conclusions from primary sources like letters and diaries. There are also “fans of science” who are not scientists or researchers, “fans of history” who are not historians or researchers, …

Study, read work by real scientists, remember the principles of scientific research, dig deeply into your narrow field and know what has been done, figure out what the real central question is (I never waste time on interesting side questions, I always figure out “the” central big question and go after answering it! You can waste time on peripheral interesting questions, but every field or area has big central questions - 1 or 2 or maybe 3, but no more). You want to be funded and successful - go after the big question. It has worked well for me for many years. Be creative, but follow the data.
